title: Implement worker registration and task execution
description:
Worker functions in client.gleam:26-40 are stubbed:
- new_worker() returns dummy ID
- start_worker_blocking() does nothing
- start_worker() returns empty closure

Required implementation:
1. Register worker with dispatcher via gRPC
2. Open persistent streaming channel for task polling
3. Implement heartbeat (every 4 seconds)
4. Execute task handlers with proper TaskContext
5. Send completion/failure events back

Depends on: gRPC implementation

Impact: CRITICAL - cannot execute any workflows.
acceptance_criteria:
## Acceptance Criteria

### Invariants
- Worker MUST register with Hatchet dispatcher on start
- Worker MUST poll for tasks via gRPC streaming
- Worker MUST execute task handlers with proper TaskContext
- Worker MUST send completion/failure events back
- Worker MUST maintain heartbeat (every 4 seconds)
- Worker MUST respect max_slots limit for concurrency

### Variants
- Start blocking (blocks until shutdown signal)
- Start non-blocking (returns cleanup function)
- Graceful shutdown (complete running tasks)
- Forced shutdown (abandon tasks)

### Happy Path
1. Create worker with client, config, workflows
2. Register workflows with Hatchet
3. Start worker (blocking or non-blocking)
4. Receive task from dispatcher stream
5. Look up handler by action ID
6. Create TaskContext with input/metadata
7. Execute handler function
8. Send completion event with output
9. Continue polling for next task

### Validation
- Register worker with local Hatchet
- Submit workflow, verify worker receives task
- Execute handler, verify completion event sent
- Test graceful shutdown
- Test concurrent task limit

### Implementation Reference  
Python: /tmp/hatchet-python/hatchet_sdk/worker/worker.py
Go: /tmp/hatchet/pkg/worker/worker.go
See: docs/HATCHET.md, docs/HATCHET_DESIGN_REVIEW.md

### Files to Modify
- src/hatchet/client.gleam - Replace stubs with real implementation
- src/hatchet/types.gleam - Ensure Worker type is complete

### Files to Create
- src/hatchet/worker.gleam - Worker process/actor

### Dependencies
- Requires: hatchet-port-8uf (gRPC implementation)

### Definition of Done
- [ ] Worker registers with Hatchet dispatcher
- [ ] Worker receives tasks via gRPC stream
- [ ] Task handlers execute with proper context
- [ ] Completion events sent back to dispatcher
- [ ] Heartbeat mechanism works
- [ ] Integration test: submit workflow, verify execution
- [ ] All existing tests pass

title: Implement durable tasks with checkpoint mechanism
description:
DurableTaskDef type exists but has no implementation:
- Checkpoint key storage
- State persistence across restarts
- DurableContext with SleepFor() method

Python/Go have full durable task support with:
- Persistent sleep
- State checkpointing
- Resume after process restart

Impact: MEDIUM - durable workflows not supported.
acceptance_criteria:
## Acceptance Criteria

### Invariants
- Durable tasks MUST survive process restarts
- Checkpoint MUST persist state to Hatchet
- SleepFor MUST be durable (continues after restart)
- DurableContext MUST extend TaskContext

### Variants
- Durable task with single checkpoint
- Durable task with multiple checkpoints
- SleepFor with various durations
- Resume from checkpoint after crash

### Happy Path
1. Create durable task with checkpoint_key
2. Task executes, reaches SleepFor(duration)
3. State checkpointed to Hatchet
4. Process crashes/restarts
5. Task resumes from checkpoint
6. Continues execution after sleep

### Validation
- Unit test DurableTaskDef creation
- Integration test checkpoint/restore cycle
- Test SleepFor persistence

### Implementation Reference
Python: /tmp/hatchet-python/hatchet_sdk/v2/callable.py (durable decorator)
Go: /tmp/hatchet/pkg/worker/context.go (DurableContext)

### Files to Modify
- src/hatchet/types.gleam - DurableTaskDef, DurableContext
- src/hatchet/task.gleam - durable() helper

### Files to Create
- src/hatchet/durable.gleam - Durable task implementation

### Definition of Done
- [ ] DurableContext type with SleepFor method
- [ ] Checkpoint mechanism implemented
- [ ] State persistence to Hatchet backend
- [ ] Resume from checkpoint works
- [ ] Integration test: crash/resume cycle
- [ ] All existing tests pass

- release_slot() - Signal early completion
- retry_count() - Get current retry attempt
- step_run_errors() - Get all step failures

- stream() MUST send streaming events to Hatchet
- refresh_timeout() MUST extend task execution timeout
- release_slot() MUST signal early task completion
- retry_count() MUST return current retry attempt number
- step_run_errors() MUST return map of all step failures

### Variants

- spawn_workflows (batch)
- stream text vs binary data

### Happy Path
1. Task handler receives TaskContext
2. Call ctx.spawn_workflow(name, input)
3. Receive WorkflowRunRef for child
4. Optionally await child result
5. Continue with task execution

### Validation

- Integration test spawn_workflow
- Test streaming with local Hatchet dashboard

Go: /tmp/hatchet/pkg/worker/context.go

- src/hatchet/task.gleam - Implement context methods

- [ ] spawn_workflows() batch version implemented
- [ ] stream() sends events to Hatchet
- [ ] refresh_timeout() extends timeout
- [ ] release_slot() signals early completion

title: Implement gRPC client for worker communication
description:
The Gleam SDK uses REST API only, but Hatchet requires gRPC for:
- Worker registration (GetActionListener)
- Task streaming (ListenV2)  
- Completion reporting (SendStepActionEvent)
- Workflow registration (PutWorkflow)

Research needed:
- Gleam gRPC libraries
- Erlang gRPC FFI options
- Protocol buffer generation for Gleam

Impact: CRITICAL - workers cannot function without gRPC.
acceptance_criteria:
## Acceptance Criteria

### Invariants
- gRPC client MUST connect to Hatchet engine on configured port
- gRPC MUST use protobuf message format
- Connection MUST support TLS (optional for local dev)
- Client MUST authenticate with Bearer token

### Variants
- Connect with TLS enabled
- Connect without TLS (insecure mode for local dev)
- Connection timeout handling
- Reconnection on disconnect

### Happy Path
1. Create gRPC client with host:port and token
2. Connect to Hatchet engine
3. Send GetActionListener request
4. Receive streaming response
5. Maintain heartbeat every 4 seconds

### Validation
- Test connection to localhost:7077 (local Hatchet)
- Verify protobuf message encoding/decoding
- Test heartbeat mechanism
- Test reconnection logic

### Research Required
- Gleam gRPC libraries (gleam_grpc or Erlang FFI)
- Protobuf code generation for Gleam
- Look at /tmp/hatchet/api-contracts/ for proto definitions

### Implementation Reference
Python: /tmp/hatchet-python/hatchet_sdk/connection.py
Go: /tmp/hatchet/pkg/client/v1/grpc-client.go

### Files to Create
- src/hatchet/internal/grpc.gleam - gRPC client
- src/hatchet/internal/grpc_ffi.gleam - Erlang FFI for gRPC

### Definition of Done
- [ ] gRPC client connects to Hatchet
- [ ] Protobuf messages encode/decode correctly
- [ ] Heartbeat mechanism works
- [ ] Integration test passes against local Hatchet
- [ ] All existing tests still pass
close_reason: Implemented gRPC client stub with TDD: 16 tests added, all 130 tests passing. Includes connect(), register_worker(), listen_v2(), send_step_event(), heartbeat(), and test helpers.

title: Implement sleep_ms function using gleam_erlang
description:
The sleep_ms function in run.gleam:302-304 currently does nothing (returns Nil). This breaks the await_result polling mechanism.

Fix: Use gleam_erlang/process.sleep() for actual sleep functionality.

Impact: CRITICAL - polling loops infinitely without this fix.
acceptance_criteria:
## Acceptance Criteria

### Invariants
- Sleep function MUST actually pause execution for the specified duration
- Sleep MUST NOT consume CPU while waiting (use Erlang timer)
- Sleep duration MUST be in milliseconds

### Variants
- Sleep with 0ms should return immediately
- Sleep with negative value should return immediately (no error)
- Sleep with very large value (> 1 hour) should work correctly

### Happy Path
1. Call sleep_ms(500)
2. Verify at least 500ms elapsed (within 50ms tolerance)
3. Verify CPU was not spinning during sleep

### Validation
- Run gleam test - all existing tests pass
- Create test sleep_ms_actually_sleeps_test to verify timing
- Verify await_result() polling works with real delays

### Implementation
Use gleam_erlang process.sleep() - see docs/GLEAM_CONVENTIONS.md

### Files
- src/hatchet/run.gleam:302-304

### Definition of Done
- [ ] sleep_ms() uses process.sleep()
- [ ] New test verifies actual sleeping  
- [ ] await_result() polling works correctly
- [ ] All 68+ tests pass
close_reason: Already implemented - timer.sleep_ms correctly uses gleam/erlang/process.sleep

title: Migrate actor API - update init and start
description:
Migrate actor init and start to builder pattern.

FILE: src/hatchet/worker/worker_actor.gleam

CHANGE actor.start to use Spec builder:

FIND:
  actor.start(init_state, fn(message, state) { handle_message(message, state) })

REPLACE:
  actor.Spec(
    init: fn() { actor.Ready(init_state, process.new_selector()) },
    init_timeout: 5000,
    loop: fn(message, state) { handle_message(message, state) }
  )
  |> actor.start()

Key changes:
1. Create Spec with init, init_timeout, loop fields
2. init returns Ready(state, selector)  
3. loop is the message handler
4. Call actor.start() on the Spec

VALIDATION:
Run: gleam check
Run: gleam test

title: Migrate actor API - update message handler signatures
description:

The Message type is removed from Next - handlers now only return Next(State).

Also update return statements:

title: Add TLS/mTLS support for secure connections
description:
Python/Go SDKs support:
- TLS encryption
- mTLS (mutual TLS) authentication
- Certificate configuration

Current Gleam SDK uses plain HTTP only.

Impact: LOW - required for production deployments.
acceptance_criteria:
## Acceptance Criteria

### Invariants
- TLS MUST encrypt all gRPC communication
- mTLS MUST require client certificate
- Certificates MUST be configurable via client options
- Insecure mode MUST be explicitly enabled

### Variants
- TLS with server verification
- mTLS with client certificate
- Insecure mode (for local development)
- Custom CA certificate

### Happy Path (TLS)
1. Create client with TLS config
2. Load CA certificate
3. Connect to Hatchet with TLS
4. Verify encrypted communication

### Happy Path (mTLS)
1. Create client with mTLS config
2. Load client cert and key
3. Connect with mutual authentication
4. Verify both sides authenticated

### Validation
- Test TLS connection to secure Hatchet
- Test mTLS with client certificates
- Test insecure mode works for local dev
- Verify certificate validation errors

### Implementation Reference
Python: /tmp/hatchet-python/hatchet_sdk/loader.py (tls_config)
Go: /tmp/hatchet/pkg/client/client.go (TLS options)
